The Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) is a metadata file format used to store and exchange multimedia data, as well as other types of resources, (such as fonts, icons, and audio samples) between different applications and platforms.
RIFF was introduced by Microsoft and IBM in the early 1990s as a way to standardize the storage and exchange of multimedia data.
Developed by Microsoft and IBM in the early 1990s, RIFF is based on the Interchange File Format (IFF) developed by Electronic Arts.
RIFF was introduced by Microsoft and IBM in 1991 as an extension to the IFF (Interchange File Format) developed by Electronic Arts.
Introduced by Microsoft in the early 1990s, RIFF files typically have a `.riff` or `.rif` extension.
RIFF files typically have a `.rif` or `.riff` extension and contain a series of chunks, each identified by a unique identifier (called a "FourCC" code) that specifies the type of data it contains.
This allows RIFF files to be flexible and extensible, able to accommodate various types of data and new formats as they emerge.
This allows RIFF files to store multiple types of data in a single file.
Each chunk can be thought of as a self-contained unit of data, along with its associated metadata.

RIFF was developed in the 1990s by Microsoft and IBM, and was widely used in the Windows platform for storing and exchanging multimedia resources such as audio and video clips, waveforms, and MIDI sequences.
RIFF was developed in the 1990s by Microsoft and IBM as a way to exchange multimedia data between their respective operating systems, Windows and OS/2.

Although it never gained widespread adoption as a universal file format, RIFF remains in use today in certain niche areas, as a convenient way to package and transmit collections of related resources.
